content.title: Hyperthyroidism
content.summary: Clinical syndrome of thyroid hormone excess causing hypermetabolic state with accelerated metabolism, cardiovascular effects, and neuromuscular symptoms
key_points: Graves' disease is the most common cause (60-80% of cases)
Suppressed TSH with elevated Free T4 and/or Free T3 confirms diagnosis
Symptoms: weight loss, tremor, tachycardia, heat intolerance, anxiety
Thyroid storm is life-threatening decompensated hyperthyroidism
Treatment: antithyroid drugs (methimazole, PTU), radioactive iodine, or surgery
Beta-blockers provide symptomatic relief while definitive treatment takes effect
Always rule out hyperthyroidism in patients with new-onset atrial fibrillation
content.statement: Hyperthyroidism is a clinical syndrome resulting from excess thyroid hormone production or release, causing a hypermetabolic state with cardiovascular, neuromuscular, and metabolic manifestations requiring definitive treatment.

explanation.intuition: If hypothyroidism is the body running too slow, hyperthyroidism is running too fast. The excess thyroid hormone accelerates metabolism, heart rate, and body temperature - like being stuck in constant overdrive.
explanation.key_insight: Distinguishing the cause of hyperthyroidism is essential for treatment selection. Graves' disease (autoimmune TSH receptor stimulation) requires antithyroid drugs or ablation. Thyroiditis (inflammatory hormone release) is self-limited and only requires supportive care.
explanation.technical_details: Thyroid hormone excess increases basal metabolic rate, protein catabolism, and thermogenesis. Cardiovascular effects include increased cardiac output, decreased systemic vascular resistance, and beta-adrenergic receptor upregulation. Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan differentiates high-uptake causes (Graves', toxic nodule) from low-uptake causes (thyroiditis, exogenous hormone).

definitions_glossary.graves_disease: Autoimmune hyperthyroidism caused by thyroid-stimulating antibodies (TSI) activating TSH receptor
definitions_glossary.toxic_multinodular_goiter: Autonomously functioning thyroid nodules causing hyperthyroidism; common in elderly
definitions_glossary.toxic_adenoma: Single autonomously functioning thyroid nodule (hot nodule)
definitions_glossary.thyroiditis: Inflammatory thyroid conditions causing transient hyperthyroidism from hormone release
definitions_glossary.thyroid_stimulating_immunoglobulin: Autoantibody that mimics TSH and stimulates thyroid hormone production (TSI)
definitions_glossary.radioactive_iodine_uptake: Nuclear medicine test differentiating causes of hyperthyroidism
definitions_glossary.methimazole: First-line antithyroid drug; inhibits thyroid peroxidase and hormone synthesis
definitions_glossary.propylthiouracil: Antithyroid drug; preferred in first trimester pregnancy and thyroid storm
definitions_glossary.thyroid_storm: Life-threatening decompensated hyperthyroidism with fever, tachycardia, altered mental status
definitions_glossary.ophthalmopathy: Graves' eye disease with proptosis, lid retraction, diplopia
definitions_glossary.pretibial_myxedema: Dermopathy specific to Graves' disease; thickened skin over shins
definitions_glossary.thyroid_acropachy: Clubbing and periosteal changes specific to Graves' disease

pathophysiology.mechanism: Excess thyroid hormone from increased synthesis (Graves', toxic nodule) or release (thyroiditis), causing hypermetabolic state with increased oxygen consumption and heat production

increased_synthesis: Toxic adenoma (Plummer's disease) - single hot nodule
increased_release: Subacute (de Quervain's) thyroiditis - painful, viral etiology
exogenous_sources: Struma ovarii (ovarian teratoma with thyroid tissue)

systemic_effects.cardiovascular: Tachycardia, widened pulse pressure, atrial fibrillation, high-output heart failure
systemic_effects.neurologic: Fine tremor, anxiety, emotional lability, hyperreflexia
systemic_effects.gastrointestinal: Weight loss despite increased appetite, hyperdefecation, diarrhea
systemic_effects.dermatologic: Warm moist skin, fine hair, onycholysis, pretibial myxedema (Graves')
systemic_effects.ophthalmologic: Lid lag, lid retraction, proptosis, diplopia (Graves' only)

laboratory_criteria.free_t3: May be elevated when T4 normal (T3 toxicosis)
laboratory_criteria.raiu_scan: High uptake = Graves'/toxic nodule; Low uptake = thyroiditis/exogenous

diagnostic_criteria.graves_specific_findings: TSI/TRAb positive, diffuse increased uptake on RAIU, ophthalmopathy, pretibial myxedema, thyroid bruit

symptomatic_treatment.beta_blockers: Propranolol 10-40 mg TID-QID or atenolol 25-100 mg daily; controls tachycardia, tremor, anxiety
symptomatic_treatment.indication: All symptomatic patients while awaiting definitive treatment

antithyroid_drugs.methimazole: First-line; 10-30 mg daily initially, then maintenance 5-10 mg daily
antithyroid_drugs.propylthiouracil: Preferred in first trimester pregnancy and thyroid storm (also blocks T4â†’T3 conversion)
antithyroid_drugs.duration: 12-18 months for Graves' disease; ~50% remission rate

radioactive_iodine.indication: Definitive treatment for Graves' and toxic nodular disease
radioactive_iodine.mechanism: I-131 destroys thyroid tissue; induces hypothyroidism
radioactive_iodine.outcome: Most patients become hypothyroid within 6-12 months; requires lifelong levothyroxine

thyroidectomy.indications: Large goiter, suspicious nodule, moderate-severe ophthalmopathy, patient preference

skos.definition: A clinical syndrome of thyroid hormone excess causing hypermetabolic state with cardiovascular, neuromuscular, and metabolic manifestations

subcodes: E05.1 - Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single nodule
E05.2 - Thyrotoxicosis with toxic multinodular goiter

learning_objectives: Differentiate causes of hyperthyroidism using RAIU scan and antibody testing
Select appropriate treatment based on etiology, patient factors, and preferences
Manage Graves' ophthalmopathy and understand its unique pathophysiology
Recognize and emergently treat thyroid storm
Apply beta-blocker therapy for symptom control
clinical_pearls: Always check thyroid function in new-onset atrial fibrillation
Suppressed TSH is the most sensitive screening test for hyperthyroidism
RAIU scan distinguishes Graves' (high uptake) from thyroiditis (low uptake)
Methimazole is preferred over PTU except in first trimester and thyroid storm
Check CBC before starting antithyroid drugs; warn patients about sore throat/fever (agranulocytosis)
Radioactive iodine can worsen Graves' ophthalmopathy; use steroids if moderate-severe
Apathetic hyperthyroidism in elderly: may present with only weight loss and atrial fibrillation
T3 toxicosis: elevated T3 with normal T4; can occur early in Graves' disease
